importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year when the LEAP trial findings were published and led to the first guidance recommending early peanut introduction in infants, marking a turning point in allergy prevention practices.
When expanded guidelines for early allergen introduction were issued, leading to a significant decline in peanut allergies across the U.S. pediatric population.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period spanning from 2015 to 2025 during which the public health effort to introduce peanuts early in infancy has been implemented and demonstrated measurable impacts on allergy rates.

keyTakeAways: Peanut allergies in U.S. children aged 0–3 declined by over 27% after 2015 and over 40% after 2017 due to early allergen introduction guidelines.
About 40,000 children have avoided peanut allergies since the 2015 guidelines were implemented, not 60,000 as previously reported.
Early introduction of peanut products (e.g., peanut butter, milk-based yogurt, soy-based yogurt) between 4 and 6 months of age is now recommended by updated guidelines from 2021.
The LEAP trial, led by Gideon Lack at King’s College London, showed that early exposure reduced peanut allergy risk by over 80% and protected about 70% of children into adolescence.

Despite the scientific evidence, adoption of guidelines was slow—only 29% of pediatricians and 65% of allergists followed the 2017 recommendations, due to confusion and concerns about implementation outside clinical settings.
The new research using electronic health records from pediatric practices shows that early allergen introduction is now being adopted and is making measurable public health impacts.
Advocates like Sung Poblete of Food Allergy Research & Education (FARE) and dietitian Tiffany Leon support early exposure as evidence-based and safe for immune system development.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A decade after the LEAP trial demonstrated that early exposure to peanuts in infancy significantly reduces the risk of developing peanut allergies, new research confirms that this public health intervention has made a measurable impact. Since 2015, peanut allergy rates in U.S. children under age 3 have declined by more than 27% and by over 40% after expanded guidelines were issued in 2017. The study, led by Dr. David Hill at Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia and published in Pediatrics, analyzed electronic health records and found that about 40,000 children have avoided peanut allergies due to early allergen introduction. Despite initial confusion among medical professionals—only 29% of pediatricians and 65% of allergists followed the recommendations—the practice is now being adopted, supported by evidence from the LEAP trial, which showed over 80% allergy risk reduction. Experts and advocacy groups like FARE now endorse early exposure to allergens such as peanut butter and soy-based products between 4 and 6 months of age as safe and effective. The findings underscore a significant shift in public health, reducing the prevalence of a life-threatening condition that once affected over 2% of children.
title: Early Peanut Introduction Reduces Allergies in U.S. Children, Study Shows
